entry.title: Re: Error importing data
entry.content:
@Ganjos , Looks like you have Data Access configured on the model. You can check it in Model settings. Check what dimensions are used to define the Data Access. In those dimensions you will have Read and Write column which controls are read and write access to those members of the dimension. The end user does not have access to the members you are loading the data to. You need to ensure the end user has write access to all members you are trying to load the data for in all secured dimensions.

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

entry.title: Different tax code behavior in F0859/FB60 ‚Äì Public vs Private
entry.content:
Hi all,

We have identified a different behavior between Private Cloud and Public Cloud in the following applications:

  • F0859 ‚Äì Create Supplier Invoices

  • FB60 ‚Äì Create Incoming Invoices

In Private Cloud, these apps/transactions allow us to enter individual tax codes in the ‚ÄúTax‚Äù tab. This way, users can combine N different tax codes within the same document.

However, in Public Cloud this behavior is not allowed (please see attached screenshots). The system forces us to use combined tax codes instead of individual ones.

Could you please help us understand:

  • Whether this behavior in Public Cloud can be configured/changed to allow multiple individual tax codes in the Tax tab (similar to Private Cloud)?

  • Or if there is any correction, SAP Note or roadmap item planned to support this behavior?

As additional context, in Argentina most customers are registered under ‚ÄúConvenio Multilateral‚Äù, so they usually require many tax combinations.

Best regards,

Blas Rosello, SAP Consultant

entry.title: Re: Deep Link to PCC
entry.content:
Hello, 

there isn't any PCC home page, but you can access each PCC app using a direct link.

The direct link should be built like the following:

https://<host>:<port>/sap/bc/ui5_ui5/sap/<hrpy_pcc_*>/index.html?sap-client=<client>&sap-ui-language=<language_code>

where:

<host>:<port> : to retrieve that information, you can use trx SMICM: Goto-->Services

/sap/bc/ui5_ui5/sap/<hrpy_pcc_*> : you should indicate the PCC service. See the whole list in the attached link:

Use Payroll Control Center | SAP Help Portal

or

Activate Payroll Control Center SAPUI5 Applications | SAP Help Portal

<client> : client of your system

<language_code> : your preferred language

In addition, you could configure FIORI launchpad (see below link) where you can define specific tile for each PCC service: 

Configure Fiori Launchpad Tiles for Payroll Control Center | SAP Help Portal

Best Regards

Giorgio

entry.title: Welcome SAP-RPT-1! What is it? How can you try it out?
entry.content:
SAP announced SAP-RPT-1 at TechEd 2025 in Berlin. What is it good for, and how can you try it out? In this blog post, I'll walk you through the announcement and show you how to get started, both in a no-code approach and in Python.

 

What is SAP-RPT-1?

RPT stands for Relational Pre-Trained Transformer which SAP wants us to pronounce as 'rapid one'. To make sure this is pronounced correctly, they even write out phonetic transcription [Ààr√¶p…™d] [w ån] - so no excuses here üòâ.

If you are looking for a quick executive summary, check out Philipp Herzig's Keynote presentation which explains that RPT-1 is a new type of AI model that is optimized for making predictions on tabular data. Unlike LLMs which generate the next word (token) for a text sequence, RPT-1 predicts the next field in a table row. Putting this in a practical example, Philipp mentions that RPT-1 can predict, for example, delivery times or customer churn, essentially replacing traditional ML models like XGBoost or Random Forest with a single RPT-1 model.

For now, SAP-RPT-1 comes in 3 flavors:

  • SAP-RPT-1-Small: A small model optimized for super-fast predictions
  • SAP-RPT-1-Large: A larger model optimized for highest accuracy
  • SAP-RPT-1-OSS: An "open source" version for everybody to learn (Github / Huggingface)

The way Philipp talked about the OSS version, I assume that this is also the version which is available in the RPT Playground, your starting point to try out RPT-1 in a no-code environment.

Trying out SAP-RPT-1 in the RPT Playground

The easiest way to get started with RPT-1 is the RPT Playground. SAP has prepared some data, but you can also upload your own tabular data (CSV files) and use RPT-1 to make predictions on it. The trick for making predictions with RPT-1 is to mask the field you want to predict with [PREDICT]. Once you click on the "Predict" button, RPT-1 will fill in the masked field with its prediction.

While SAP's prepared use cases work well, you'll get a better sense of RPT-1's capabilities by trying it with your own data. To help you get started, I've prepared the example data from the coding tutorial (allowing you to predict sales groups from Product, Price, Customer, Country) in a CSV file for you to download. You can easily modify this file in Excel (or any other editor), save as CSV and try your own data in the RPT Playground. If you'd prefer to start simple, try out the example CSV file I have prepared for you.

If you're not a coder, simply skip the coding section and jump right to the conclusion.

 
 

Trying out SAP-RPT-1 in Python

If you want to get your hands dirty with code, I have prepared a Jupyter notebook that shows in detail how to use RPT-1.

Prerequisites

Assuming you have access to the RPT Playground and that you have downloaded the Jupyter notebook, you need to fetch your access token from the bottom of the playground page.

To avoid storing your credentials in the notebook, copy & paste the token (RPT_TOKEN) into a .env file in the same folder where you have stored the Jupyter notebook. It should look like this:

RPT_TOKEN="eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1" # truncated, your token is a lot longer

Once you've done that, you're ready to run the notebook.

 
 

Preparing Test Data

Here's the test data in the format RPT-1 expects:

 
payload = {
    "prediction_config": {
        "target_columns": [
            {
                "name": "SALESGROUP",
                "prediction_placeholder": "[PREDICT]"
                # "task_type": "classification" or "regression" can be specified here if needed
            }
        ]
    },
    "index_column": "ID",
    "rows": [
        {
            "ID": "1001",
            "PRODUCT": "Tablet",
            "PRICE": 599.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "TechStart Inc",
            "COUNTRY": "USA",
            "SALESGROUP": "[PREDICT]"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1002",
            "PRODUCT": "Standing Desk",
            "PRICE": 325.50,
            "CUSTOMER": "Workspace Solutions",
            "COUNTRY": "Germany",
            "SALESGROUP": "[PREDICT]"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1003",
            "PRODUCT": "Workstation",
            "PRICE": 1450.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "Enterprise Systems Ltd",
            "COUNTRY": "Canada",
            "SALESGROUP": "Enterprise Solutions"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1004",
            "PRODUCT": "Laptop Pro",
            "PRICE": 1899.99,
            "CUSTOMER": "Business Corp",
            "COUNTRY": "UK",
            "SALESGROUP": "Enterprise Solutions"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1005",
            "PRODUCT": "Gaming Laptop",
            "PRICE": 1250.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "Digital Ventures",
            "COUNTRY": "USA",
            "SALESGROUP": "Enterprise Solutions"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1006",
            "PRODUCT": "Smart Watch",
            "PRICE": 299.99,
            "CUSTOMER": "Gadget Store",
            "COUNTRY": "Australia",
            "SALESGROUP": "Consumer Electronics"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1007",
            "PRODUCT": "Ergonomic Chair",
            "PRICE": 445.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "Office Outfitters",
            "COUNTRY": "France",
            "SALESGROUP": "Office Furniture"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1008",
            "PRODUCT": "Storage Array",
            "PRICE": 3500.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "CloudTech Systems",
            "COUNTRY": "Singapore",
            "SALESGROUP": "Data Infrastructure"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1009",
            "PRODUCT": "Network Switch",
            "PRICE": 175.50,
            "CUSTOMER": "ConnectIT",
            "COUNTRY": "Japan",
            "SALESGROUP": "Networking Devices"
        }
    ]
}
 
 

For better readability, here is the data in table format:

 
import pandas as pd

sample_data = pd.DataFrame(payload["rows"])
sample_data
 
  ID PRODUCT PRICE CUSTOMER COUNTRY SALESGROUP012345678
1001Tablet599.00TechStart IncUSA[PREDICT]
1002Standing Desk325.50Workspace SolutionsGermany[PREDICT]
1003Workstation1450.00Enterprise Systems LtdCanadaEnterprise Solutions
1004Laptop Pro1899.99Business CorpUKEnterprise Solutions
1005Gaming Laptop1250.00Digital VenturesUSAEnterprise Solutions
1006Smart Watch299.99Gadget StoreAustraliaConsumer Electronics
1007Ergonomic Chair445.00Office OutfittersFranceOffice Furniture
1008Storage Array3500.00CloudTech SystemsSingaporeData Infrastructure
1009Network Switch175.50ConnectITJapanNetworking Devices
 
#sample_data.to_csv("sample_data.csv", index=False)
 
 

As you can see, we have 4 attribute columns: Product, Price, Customer, Country. Our target column is the Sales Group. Therefore, the sales group is masked in 2 lines with the value [PREDICT], so that RPT-1 can demonstrate that it can fill in the missing values.

 
 

Running the predictions

To run the predictions, we will use the requests library to send an HTTP POST request to the RPT-1 API endpoint. The request will include our test data and the authorization token.

 
#!pip install python-dotenv # install if not already installed
 
from dotenv import load_dotenv
import os

load_dotenv()

auth_token = os.getenv("RPT_TOKEN")
 
import requests

url = "https://rpt.cloud.sap/api/predict"

headers = {
    "Content-Type": "application/json",
    "Authorization": f"Bearer {auth_token}"
}

response = requests.post(url, json=payload, headers=headers)
 
 

Analyzing the results

Let's take a look at the results returned by RPT-1. Here are the predictions in the raw JSON format:

 
import json

data = response.json()
preds = data["prediction"]["predictions"]
print(json.dumps(preds, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False))
 
[
  {
    "ID": 1001,
    "SALESGROUP": [
      {
        "confidence": null,
        "prediction": "Enterprise Solutions"
      }
    ]
  },
  {
    "ID": 1002,
    "SALESGROUP": [
      {
        "confidence": null,
        "prediction": "Office Furniture"
      }
    ]
  }
]
 
 

Let's merge these predictions back into the tabular format to see the results more clearly.

 
preds_df = sample_data.copy(deep=True)

preds_df["ID"] = preds_df["ID"].astype(int)

for pred in preds:
    row_idx = int(pred["ID"])
    predicted_value = pred["SALESGROUP"][0]["prediction"]
    preds_df.loc[preds_df["ID"] == row_idx, "SALESGROUP"] = predicted_value

preds_df
 
  ID PRODUCT PRICE CUSTOMER COUNTRY SALESGROUP012345678
1001Tablet599.00TechStart IncUSAEnterprise Solutions
1002Standing Desk325.50Workspace SolutionsGermanyOffice Furniture
1003Workstation1450.00Enterprise Systems LtdCanadaEnterprise Solutions
1004Laptop Pro1899.99Business CorpUKEnterprise Solutions
1005Gaming Laptop1250.00Digital VenturesUSAEnterprise Solutions
1006Smart Watch299.99Gadget StoreAustraliaConsumer Electronics
1007Ergonomic Chair445.00Office OutfittersFranceOffice Furniture
1008Storage Array3500.00CloudTech SystemsSingaporeData Infrastructure
1009Network Switch175.50ConnectITJapanNetworking Devices
 
 

For comparison, here is the original sample data before predictions:

 
sample_data
 
  ID PRODUCT PRICE CUSTOMER COUNTRY SALESGROUP012345678
1001Tablet599.00TechStart IncUSA[PREDICT]
1002Standing Desk325.50Workspace SolutionsGermany[PREDICT]
1003Workstation1450.00Enterprise Systems LtdCanadaEnterprise Solutions
1004Laptop Pro1899.99Business CorpUKEnterprise Solutions
1005Gaming Laptop1250.00Digital VenturesUSAEnterprise Solutions
1006Smart Watch299.99Gadget StoreAustraliaConsumer Electronics
1007Ergonomic Chair445.00Office OutfittersFranceOffice Furniture
1008Storage Array3500.00CloudTech SystemsSingaporeData Infrastructure
1009Network Switch175.50ConnectITJapanNetworking Devices
 
 

Conclusion

As we can see, RPT-1 has filled in the missing sales groups based on the patterns contained in the context, i.e., the other entries. Essentially, the non-masked rows serve as few-shot examples that RPT-1 uses for in-context learning. This behavior is comparable to an LLM imitating examples you provide in a prompt. Here's a simple example of such a prompt:

Write an executive summary for the Lord of the Rings.

Here is an example for Romeo and Juliet:
Boy and girl fall in love, in the end they both die.

If you try this prompt, you might get a result like this:

Guy inherits ring. Walks a lot. Destroys it.

Similarly, RPT-1 uses the non-masked rows as examples to predict the masked values. The key difference is that RPT-1 does not semantically generate text, but it predicts the most likely value for the masked fields based on the patterns it has learned during training.

Of course, the example we used is very simple, and it will be interesting to see how RPT-1 performs on more complex datasets. For now, I hope you are all set to try SAP-RPT-1 with your own data. Happy experimenting!

entry.title: New version 8.6 of the SAP Cryptographic Library with quantum-safe cryptography and FIPS 140-3 mode
entry.content:
Overview

The SAP Cryptographic Library enables applications like SAP S/4 HANA to support security protocols such as TLS (Transport Layer Security), SNC (Secure Network Communication), SSF (Secure Store and Forward) and X.509. While the library already includes "modern" cryptographic algorithms such as those based on Elliptic Curve Cryptography, these were until now all part of the group of "classic" algorithms. 

Most "classic" algorithms for asymmetric cryptography are vulnerable when a cryptographically relevant quantum computer becomes reality. This might have an impact even today if attackers record encrypted communication and store it for later decryption ("harvest-now-decrypt-later"). 

Quantum-safe cryptography in the SAP Cryptographic Library

The new version 8.6 of the library enables support for a quantum-safe TLS 1.3 handshake. When the library is installed on an SAP NetWeaver ABAP system and TLS 1.3 is used to establish a connection, then a hybrid ECDHE-MLKEM key agreement based on X25519MLKEM768 takes place. ML-KEM is a new, quantum-safe algorithm for key encapsulation, which was already standardized as FIPS-203. This makes it impossible, even for a quantum computer, to determine the session key and decrypt the session communication. 

New FIPS 140-3 certification of the FIPS crypto kernel

FIPS stands for Federal Information Processing Standard. A FIPS certification is required by US public sector agencies, healthcare, and financial industries, and many more. FIPS 140-3 validates the proper implementation of the algorithms in cryptographic modules.

The FIPS crypto kernel is a dedicated module in the SAP Cryptographic Library that was recently certified as compliant with FIPS 140-3. The certificate is available from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST): Certificate #5093.

For SAP Application Server ABAP and SAP HANA, SAP note 2180024 explains the configuration steps that are required to switch the SAP Cryptographic Library to FIPS mode.

Release Details

The release note "3685428 - Fixes and features in CommonCryptoLib 8.6.2" has now been published. More information about the SAP Cryptographic Library is available in "1848999 - Central Note for CommonCryptoLib 8 (SAPCRYPTOLIB)".

entry.title: Re: Hi Experts,I need your guidance. We are working in SA...
entry.content:
Yes, instead of relying on 309 material-to-material transfer, stage-wise SFG inventory updates using production order‚Äìbased postings (movement 261/101) or custom goods receipt processes with batch management is possible, which allow system-generated batches and capture process losses more naturally than 309 transfers. But I am not sure, whether production order creation is possible since your post says not fully configured.

So the work around would be

  • Movement 501 (GR without PO) ‚Üí Create stock for the new material with a fresh batch.
  • Movement 201/202 (issue to cost center) ‚Üí To reflect consumption/loss of input material.

Together, these mimic stage-wise consumption and creation without PP orders.

entry.title: SAP Advanced Financial Closing - definition of Parameters
entry.content:
Hello team,

  • in the documentation of SAP advanced financial closing I read here for Fiori App integration: "During this navigation SAP Advanced Financial Closing also forwards parameters, such as ledger, fiscal year or period, to the SAP Fiori application. The parameter information is taken from the task list."
  • "Such as" leads me to the expectation that I configure the parameters for Fiori Apps somewhere in AFC. So I look into the task list models, task lists and task template definition and find nothing regarding this topic.
  • Then I look into How to Maintain Task Parameters". This description sounds to me that I can define parameters on all levels. Great!
  • Then I find in Parameter Maintenance: "Parameters apply to tasks of the types Job and Workflow that require this particular parameter. During task processing, the parameters are forwarded from SAP Advanced Financial Closing to the corresponding report or workflow and are applied."

So is it now possible to define parameters for Fiori Apps or not? Is it possible to use standard parameters, e.g. variance, for Fiori Apps, or not?

Best regards

Christian

entry.title: Re: Get the price for a material without simulating sales...
entry.content:
The best approach is to:

  1. Build a custom CDS view on condition record tables (Axxx, KONP) for condition type PR00.

  2. Use that CDS in your custom app to fetch prices for multiple materials at once.

  3. If you need full net price (with discounts, freight, taxes), keep BAPI as fallback.

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Errors during the Mass Creati...
entry.content:
Hello @LukasKuhn

Yes,  grouping relationships involving the same BP into one set of 100 can significantly help avoid the locking conflicts you are currently facing. Considering creation happens in parallel background jobs, if the same BP appears across different parallel jobs, it can easily cause deadlocks or serialization issues, especially since SAP_WFRT attempts to lock and activate those records simultaneously.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to Manage Inventory Count and Adjustment in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Welcome! In this blog, you‚Äôll see how the physical inventory counting and adjustment process works in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.
We‚Äôll also explore the latest capabilities of the new app ‚ÄúManage Physical Inventory Item List‚Äù, which brings more visibility, speed, and simplicity to your inventory operations.

Our goal is to help you use these functionalities with confidence ‚Äî and we‚Äôd love to hear from you!
If you have experiences, questions, or suggestions, feel free to leave a comment at the end of this post.

Before You Start: What You Need to Know

The full process is described in detail in the test script BML ‚Äì Physical Inventory ‚Äì Inventory Count and Adjustment, including prerequisites, system access requirements, and business conditions.

https://me.sap.com/processnavigator/SolS/EARL_SolS-013/2508/SolP/BML?region=DE

One optional (but very valuable) preliminary step is setting up Situation Handling. With it, the system can automatically trigger notifications, messages, or even emails when a counting difference occurs ‚Äî helping your team react faster and more accurately.

Let‚Äôs take a look at what you can configure.

  1. Configure Situation Handling (optional but recommended)

To use Situation Handling, the scope item 31N ‚Äì Situation Handling must be activated.

Manage Teams and Responsibilities app

In this app, you can:

  • Create, edit, copy, and delete teams
  • Assign a global team ID
  • Enable or disable team status directly from the overview
  • Assign team owners responsible for the team setup
  • Assign functions to multiple members at once

  • Create team owners who are responsible for a team header, responsibility definitions, team members and their functions.

  • Maintain responsibility definitions for teams.
  • Replace a team member (Business Partner ID) across teams

Help Portal: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a624a4a6d1d8473eb95fb42660127cfe/bdc5c6a612a043ed913e22159b5a4f42.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US

Learning journey: https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition/managing-teams-and-responsibilities

Manage Situation Types app

Here, you define when and how the system should notify the responsible users.

Steps:

  1. Open Manage Situation Types
  2. Look for MAN_PHYSICAL_INVENTORY_MONITOR
  • If not available, create it using the test script as a reference

You can define:

  • Trigger conditions
  • Recipients
  • Notification layout (Launchpad message + email)

  • Scheduled jobs for automated notifications

Help Portal: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/60748ea9f37d4692912578b698aaefee.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US

  1. Starting the Physical Inventory Process

Step 1: Create the Physical Inventory Document

Using the Create Physical Inventory Document app, you can create:

  • A single document for one material
  • A mass creation for multiple materials

You can also enable Set Posting Block (under Additional Header Data).
When activated, no postings can be made for that material until counting is completed.

If a user tries to post during counting, the system will show an error message similar to the image below:

You can additionally schedule the creation of Physical inventory documents, splitting them by: Storage bin, Material, Material group.

Step 2: Print the Inventory Document

Open Manage Physical Inventory Documents app, search for your document, and select Background Print.
You can view the generated PDF under:
Output Management ‚Üí Display Details

Step 3: Perform the Physical Counting

Once you have printed the documents, your team performs the physical count at the shop floor.

P.S.: You have the possibility to edit this PDF file, for example by adding your company‚Äôs logo. Help Portal: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/bd637484dc2f47a5a9071157f388ccd8.html

  1. Post Counting Results

Step 4: Enter Counting Results

In the Manage Physical Inventory Count app, click the Edit icon to enter the results.

You can:

  • Enter quantities manually
  • Upload results using an Excel template provided by SAP

Thresholds for tolerances can be configured using SSCUI 106788 ‚Äì Manage Tolerances for Physical Inventory Differences.
If a difference is detected and Situation Handling is configured, the responsible user will automatically be notified.

Step 5: Reviewing the Results
With the new Manage Physical Inventory Items app, you can perform the following actions:

  • View counted quantities
  • View identified differences
  • View the cost impact on stock
  • Perform mass postings or mass recounts ‚Äî speeding up the process

You can also filter inventory items using multiple available dimensions.

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F8634')/S35

Step 7: Analyze the Inventory Results

Use the Physical Inventory Analysis app to get a complete overview of your inventory performance.
For example, you can summarize differences by plant and material.

Through Navigate to, you can access more analysis options such as:

  • Analyze Stock in Date Range, where you can compare beginning and ending stock values and generate useful insights.

We Want to Hear From You!

As mentioned at the beginning, your feedback is extremely valuable.
Feel free to leave your questions, comments, or suggestions ‚Äî let‚Äôs improve this process together!

Useful links:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/76984c36687f413391531bed71e51259.html

https://community.sap.com/t5/financial-management-q-a/add-a-reason-to-the-physical-inventory-document/qaq-p/14267467

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/physical-inventory-goods-movement-types-701-702-and-711-712/qaq-p/12317683

entry.title: Re: ERROR 80101
entry.content:
Hi @mo-shabeer ,

Note that in most SAP Data Services landscapes, the Designer and Job Server components run on separate machines, and in some cases, the Job Server operates on Linux while the Designer runs on Windows. This distributed architecture creates important considerations for file access. When a job needs to access local files, the file path must be accessible from the Job Server machine and not just the Designer machine. The issue you are facing is a common issue that occurs when occurs when the file path is valid and accessible from the Designer machine but the same path is either inaccessible from the Job Server machine, or the path exists but the required file is not present on the Job Server

Regards Joe !

entry.title: SAC Import job fails in first step (gather data)

Hello experts,

We are building a new SAP Analytics Cloud for planning solution and have an import job that has previously run without issues for weeks. We are extracting data from an S/4HANA on prem system (QA environment) to an SAC Dev tenant, so nothing is productive at this point. Suddenly the job started failing in the first step  (or couldn't be created, if we tried to create a new and identical import job). We are using oData service UI_FINS_GLACCOUNTFLOW to fetch data from the GLAccountBalanceFlow view.

After playing around with fields and filters in the job, it has been established that the Profit center and Cost center fields are causing the job to fail. If these fields are omitted, the job completes successfully. However, these fields are critical for the solution.

The error messages in SAC are many but fairly bland and there are no entries in the SAC monitor (trace).

The problem is not caused by missing authorizations, as even if the SAC user gets SAP_ALL in S4, the job still fails. Does anyone have any suggestions on what to investigate next in order to identify the root cause? As I said, the job ran fine for weeks and the suddenly started to fail.

Also, running the job importing data from S/4 DEV environment runs without issues, so the issue appears when trying to import from  S/4 QA.

I appreciate any inputs.

Thanks

‚ÄÉ

entry.title: Re: SAP Data Services Job "Hangs" Occasionally. Requires...
entry.content:
@dunncrew

to abort the job, if you are on Linux, you can create a script that monitors the al_engine using a combination of various utilities and comparing the results after some time and if there is no al_engine activity for some time you can consider the process hanged and terminate it. 

# Process state, context switches, memory usage 
cat /proc/$PID/status 

# I/O activity (read/write bytes) 
cat /proc/$PID/io | grep -E "(read_bytes|write_bytes)"; 

# CPU time (user + system) 
cat /proc/$PID/stat 
# Real-time snapshot (CPU%, state, memory) 

top -p $PID

For windows i recommend searching the windows equivalent to the above commands.

you would need to come up with a way to grab the al_engine process ID once they are launched so you can start grabbing the metrics from the commands above. You can also think of better ways to monitor

entry.title: BiWhy ‚Äì Web Intelligence Processing Server (WEBI) Memory
entry.content:
Disclaimer:
BiWhy is available again for FREE to everyone on biwhy.net

BOBJ Sizing Guide:
‚ÄòEnable Memory Analysis‚Äô is now unchecked by default when you perform a new installation from BI 4.2 onwards... We now recommend this is disabled as your default setting, enabling the process to use as much memory as it needs and without the need to reclaim memory or generate any related error due to memory limits becoming breached.

But I strongly recommend always keeping it enabled to protect the host memory from being exhausted by WEBI.

 

The exhaustion can happen for two reasons: 

Memory leak.

I once saw WEBI consume 100 GB during an Excel export. I am sure this specific issue was fixed long ago, but nobody can guarantee that the code is fully leak free.

Real load:

  • Multiple concurrent users
  • A few users running very large reports
  • A combination of both

 

Think about Memory Thresholds the same way you think about the Java Xmx parameter.

If thresholds are reached, the system will handle the situation gracefully. In the worst case, WEBI will be restarted, which impacts only the users assigned to this specific WEBI.
If thresholds are not set, the same scenario may cause the entire host to run out of memory, which can lead to system-down situations or worse. What do you prefer?

Here is a conservative formula for calculating memory allocation for WEBI:
WEBI_MAX = Available_RAM ‚Äì Sum of Xmx (APS and others) ‚Äì 2 GB for OS ‚Äì 2 to 4 GB for CMS (or more, depending on actual usage) ‚Äì Xmx for Tomcats if they run on the same host ‚Äì other major memory consumers on the server.

My recommendation: set thresholds high enough that they are never reached during normal operation, but still low enough to avoid endangering the host memory.

Why does the Sizing Guide recommend switching off Memory Analysis?

I do not know for sure, but the most likely reason is related to thresholds configuration.
Thresholds must be customized for each system. They cannot be set correctly by default, because default values would be either too high or too low.

BOBJ administrators need to understand what Lower, Upper, and Maximum Thresholds mean and how to connect the warning messages seen by end users to these configured parameters, so they can adjust thresholds or upscale the system instead of opening incidents.

A possible improvement on the SAP side would be to explicitly state in warning messages that they originate from the Memory Analysis configuration.

Threshold meaning from Admin Guide:
If this property is enabled then the following properties will be active and recognized by the server:

  • Memory Maximum Threshold
  • Memory Upper Threshold
  • Memory Lower Threshold

If the Memory Lower Threshold limit is reached, the server swaps out inactive documents onto the hard disk allocating additional memory for the documents which are active. Each user is allowed to have up to one active document instead of Maximum Documents per User.

If this Memory Upper Threshold is reached, the following server actions will take place in order to free resources and protect the server:

  • The server will reject new connections and new client calls. Only the option to Save Web Intelligence documents will be allowed. Users that request an action will receive a Server Busy message, and they will be notified that they should save any pending changes.
  • The server will turn on system cleanup to free enough resources so that the amount of allocated memory is below the limit set by the Memory Upper Threshold property.
  • The server tries to close read-only documents.
  • If not enough memory was freed during system cleanup then the server will begin to close documents that are in Editing mode. The server will begin to close documents based on the LIFO protocol; the most recent active document will be purged from memory first. The server will continue to close documents until a safe level is reached; this level is based on the following calculation: Memory Upper Threshold - (20%*(Memory Upper Threshold)). For example, if the Memory Upper Threshold property is set to 4.5GB then the safe level would be: 4.5GB - 20%*4.5GB = 3.6GB
  • The server cannot close documents when a client call is running. Any document that is refreshed or exported to another format or any other time consuming operation will not be closed when the server reaches this threshold. If the server cannot recover enough memory and is still above the Memory Upper Threshold, it restarts.

If the Memory Maximum Threshold limit is reached, all current operations abort. All client calls will be terminated. Once the a call terminates, the corresponding document will be closed.

Or shortly:

When the server's process memory is above the Memory Upper Threshold, the only operation that is allowed is saving documents.

When the process memory is above the Memory Maximum Threshold, all operations stop and fail.

Screenshots:

Content:

  • BOBJ Metrics: cumulative WEBI usage of 430 GB, with recommendations on WEBIs per host
  • BOBJ Metrics: individual WEBI usage reaching 74 GB
  • OS-level monitoring: cumulative WEBI allocation of 450 GB

Here is a production system with 800 sessions. Cumulative WEBI memory usage reaches 430 GB, with individual WEBI processes using up to 52 GB.
You can see multiple WEBI servers per host. SAP recommends one WEBI per host, or two for failover if the system has only a few WEBI nodes. Although in the past we observed during VTOs that in some cases multiple WEBIs perform better, for simplicity and to reduce communication overhead I recommend fewer WEBIs unless there is a clear reason to do otherwise.

Here is a VTO run with 1,400 sessions, with a WEBI process consuming up to 74 GB

OS-level monitoring shows that on a system with only 46 active sessions, WEBI on two nodes cumulatively consumes about 450 GB.
However, I do not believe this reflects real memory usage ‚Äì it is rather allocated memory. This is mainly due to the customer running 10 WEBI servers per host, with Memory Analysis switched off and 1 TB of RAM available per processing node.

entry.title: Attachments / Folder Permissions
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

entry.title: How to analyze error message inconsistent amounts F5 704 in Migration Cockpit?
entry.content:
Dear SAP S/4HANA Experts,

during the migration of customer open items using the migration object ‚ÄúFI ‚Äì Accounts receivable open item‚Äù, one open item is not being migrated. Instead, the following error messages occur:

  • ‚ÄúInconsistent amounts‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúError in document: BKPFF $ CDACLNT275‚Äù

When I analyze the relevant open items in the SAP ERP source system using transaction FBL5N (Customer Line Items), document 6293930 contains two line items:

  • one line item with H Debit/Credit Ind. and a negative amount of -1,065.07 EUR
  • another line item with S Debit/Credit Ind. and a positive amount of 57.55 EUR

Both line items are listed identically in the XML template file as well as in the staging table.

However, only the line item with S Debit/Credit Ind. and the positive amount of 57.55 EUR is migrated into the SAP S/4HANA test system.

The source structure of the migration object ‚ÄúFI ‚Äì Accounts receivable open item‚Äù does not contain a field for the Debit/Credit Ind.. Therefore, I assume that the Migration Cockpit derives the Debit/Credit Ind. of an open item solely based on the sign of the value in the field ‚ÄúAmount in doc curr.‚Äù. We are migrating the customer open items into an SAP S/4HANA test system in which no user exits, such as EXIT_SAPLV60B_002, EXIT_SAPLV60B_008, or similar enhancements, have been implemented.

At present, I am unable to clearly interpret the cause of these error messages from a functional perspective.

Could this be a misunderstanding on my side, or is this a limitation or issue within the Migration Cockpit?
What solution or recommended approach would you suggest in this case?

Kind regards,
Emal Rahman

entry.title: Re: Custom Adobe Form How to Print 7 Outputs with Differe...
entry.content:
Hello @kranti_babhulkar

Answer on how to detect the copy number:

Since your backend only sends one data payload and you are repeating the subform manually, you need to use the instanceIndex method provided by Adobe LiveCycle scripting to determine the current iteration index. Basically, you need to use JavaScript inside the repeated subform; inside the header label field of the repeated subform. Make sure the script runs on form ready or initialize and not on calculate, so it executes once per iteration.

Answer to Line item not repeating inside each copy:

This seems to be a structure issue in your form layout and probably your line items subform is outside the repeating block. Which probably makes it render only once. I suggest you move all layout into the repeatable subform. Make sure the entire invoice layout (Header section, Line items table and Totals) is place inside the repeatable parent subform.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA 2025 Fully-Activated Appliance: Known Issues
entry.content:
This blog covers latest information and known issues for the SAP S/4HANA 2025 Fully-Activated Appliance, delivered via SAP Cloud Appliance Library (SAP CAL).
The overview blog for the appliance can be found here.
The known issues for older appliance releases are here: 2023 / 2022 / 
If you would like to ask a support question, please do so in the SAP CAL Community.

Technical Topics

Initial system performance after instance creation or re-activate

When you create an instance or suspend / re-activate it, the system performance will be slower, especially within the Fiori Launchpad. Also, the first click on a Fiori tile will be significantly slower. This is due to initial caching in the system and will become faster if you continue working.
Other performance tuning tips are:

    • Choose the cloud provider location nearest to you (for good network latency)
    • The demo users contain a relatively large number of roles and Fiori tiles. You can copy these demo users in TCode SU01 and adapt accordingly e.g. remove roles, create your own roles / Fiori catalogs, or personalize the Fiori launchpad (see also the SAP Fiori Rapid Activation demo guide on the appliance demo page).

Note: SGEN has been performed to pre-compile ABAP coding.

Initial demo users (S4H_.... and others) are locked

This works as intended and helps to increase the security of newly created appliances. Please log on with DDIC or SAP* and unlock them. They usually still have the password Welcome1, hence, it is recommended to assign a new (strong) password after unlocking them. Another alternative is copying the default users to your own user IDs.

Transport system (STMS) is not configured by default

Please check the SAP standard documentation how to configure the transport system in a new system.

Issues with specific business scenarios

Fiori Content Manager (transaction /UI2/FLPCM_CUST): ABAP dump when assigning a catalog to a role

Symptom:
In /UI2/FLPCM_CUST > Catalog tab > Search for a catalog > Click ‚ÄúShow usage in roles‚Äù (upper pane) > Click ‚ÄúAssign role‚Äù (lower pane) >  Choose a role and click OK > Runtime error ‚ÄúOBJECTS_OBJREF_NOT_ASSIGNED_NO‚Äù occurs

Solution / Workaround:
Before starting the above sequence, switch once from the catalogs tab to the roles tab and then back to the catalogs tab; then the error does not occur.

Data Migration Cockpit

The demo scenarios for "direct transfer" are not available with the initial release of the SAP S/4HANA 2025 Fully-Activated Appliance.

entry.title: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data set¬†using more than one value of this property
entry.content:
Hi,
 
We need to filter a data entity using the filter conditions input of a "Get record collection" activity in Build Apps. For this, we use the following formula in the Formula Editor:
 
{type: "and", conditions: [{type: "eq", property: ["account.id"], value: appVars.collectedAccountTechnicalIds[0].accountTechnicalId}]}
 
appVars.collectedAccountTechnicalIds is the variable where we store the values needed to filter the data set. It is a list of objects with one property (accountTechnicalId).
 
The formula works well, but as you can see, we're filtering using the first occurrence of the array only ([0]), which results in showing the records filtered on this value only. We've made countless tests but they're always returning errors, for instance:
 
{type: "and", conditions: [{type: "eq", property: ["account.id"], value: appVars.collectedAccountTechnicalIds}]}
 
So the question is: using the Formula Editor, is there a simple way to apply the filter using all the values stored in the variable? Else, is there some sort of "for each" activity or should we create a loop or use a JS script in the logic canva? Basically, the goal here is to apply a filter on a single property of a data set using one or more values of this property.
 
Thanks a lot for your help on this, we're stuck on this problem for quite some time now and we need to implement this urgently for a demo to a client next Thursday...
 
Best regards,
 
LM.

entry.title: BW vs. Datasphere (DSP) & SAC
entry.content:
From a functional and development perspective, SAP BW and the combination of Datasphere (DSP) and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) represent two different generations of SAP‚Äôs data & analytics stack.

  • BW is feature‚Äërich and comes with many out‚Äëof‚Äëthe‚Äëbox capabilities: tightly integrated data warehousing, mature modeling, and predefined mechanisms for enhancements and reporting.
  • DSP/SAC provides a leaner programming and configuration set, which often requires a ‚Äúdo‚Äëit‚Äëyourself‚Äù approach: more scripting, more custom logic, and more architectural decisions on the customer side.

However, DSP/SAC are actively and rapidly evolving. Each release brings new features‚Äîand sometimes new issues, especially in SAC‚Äîbut the overall trajectory clearly indicates that DSP/SAC are the strategic future. Over the long term, the flexibility, cloud‚Äënative approach, and continuous innovation of DSP & SAC are expected to outgrow and eventually surpass BW in capability and relevance.

How-To implement BW functionality in DSP/SAC:

Architecture DSP: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-architecture-and-security-concept/ba-p/13702030

BW Security like in DSP/SAC: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/bw-like-authorizations-in-datasphere-dsp/ba-p/14153918

Generic-like extraction into DSP: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-delta-extraction/ba-p/13699391

BW to DSP extraction using ODP: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-bw-odp-delta-via-replication-flow/ba-p/13739830

entry.title: The Re-emergence of Community in the SAP Ecosystem
entry.content:
Over the past year, I‚Äôve found myself thinking a lot about the role of community in our SAP world, particularly as in-person events and hybrid engagement have started to return.

I wanted to try something a little different here. The post below is written deliberately in a more reflective, neutral style to frame the topic and create some shared ground for discussion.

I‚Äôll add my own more personal perspective as the first comment.

I‚Äôm genuinely interested in how others are experiencing this. What‚Äôs changed? What hasn‚Äôt? And what actually matters when it comes to community?

 

Professional communities have always played an important role in how knowledge is shared, interpreted, and applied within enterprise software environments. Beyond formal training, documentation, and product announcements, communities create space for practitioners to exchange experiences, challenge assumptions, and develop shared ways of thinking about complex problems.

Over the last few years, the nature of professional engagement has shifted significantly. During the period of predominantly virtual interaction, access to content increased, but many practitioners observed a reduction in the depth of discussion and informal exchange that typically occurs when people spend time together in the same physical space.

More recently, there are signs that this balance is shifting again. As in-person and hybrid events return, conversations within the SAP community appear to be changing in tone and focus. Rather than centring on product updates alone, many discussions are returning to architectural questions, trade-offs, and the practical realities of implementing and operating SAP landscapes in complex organisations.

A notable aspect of this shift is where meaningful interaction takes place. Some of the most substantive exchanges do not occur during formal sessions, but in the informal spaces around them, where practitioners speak candidly about what has worked, what has not, and why. These conversations often surface insights that are difficult to capture in structured presentations, yet are critical to informed decision-making.

In the context of ongoing change, including cloud adoption, clean core strategies, and the growing influence of AI in enterprise systems, the role of community becomes increasingly important. Many of the challenges organisations face cannot be resolved through technical guidance alone. They require interpretation, judgement, and an understanding of how theory meets reality.

From this perspective, professional communities serve as an essential complement to formal governance and architecture processes. They provide an environment where shared understanding can develop, assumptions can be tested, and collective learning can occur. While the platforms and formats of engagement continue to evolve, the underlying value of community lies in sustained dialogue and the willingness to engage openly with complexity.

entry.title: Re: The Re-emergence of Community in the SAP Ecosystem
entry.content:
I wanted to add a more personal note to this, because the post above is intentionally written in a more neutral, reflective way.

Over the last year, being back at in-person SAP events in Berlin, Sydney and Melbourne, what‚Äôs stood out to me most hasn‚Äôt been the content or the slide decks. It‚Äôs been the conversations. They‚Äôve felt deeper and more honest than they have in a long time, focused less on announcements and more on architecture, trade-offs, and what actually works in the real world.

Some of the most valuable discussions didn‚Äôt happen in sessions at all, but in the spaces around them. That‚Äôs where people tend to be more open about what‚Äôs hard, where things break down, and how they‚Äôve adapted. That‚Äôs the part of community I personally missed during the fully virtual period, and a period I am enjoying again as the energy returns to full-scale in person events.

I‚Äôm curious whether others are experiencing the same shift, or something different. Are the conversations changing where you are? And if so, what do you think is driving it?

entry.title: Re: Understanding Non Valuated Stock and Text Items in SA...
entry.content:
Hi @AAkash1,

Non‚Äëvaluated stock in SAP MM/EWM means materials are physically tracked but carry no financial value in the system. This is useful for items like free‚Äëof‚Äëcharge samples, customer‚Äëowned stock, or certain packaging materials. EWM still requires product master data to represent them, but no accounting postings are triggered. Text items in EWM are purely informational‚Äîthey don‚Äôt create deliveries or warehouse tasks, with no exceptions for execution processes.

The No-valued material in practice because, the materials are tracked with both quantity and value; every goods movement posts to accounting. Even Non‚Äëvaluated stock materials are tracked only in terms of quantity; no financial postings occur. Business implication for the company knows what is physically in the warehouse but does not assign a book value to it.

Business Processes Where Non‚ÄëValuated Stock Makes Sense as Customer‚Äëowned stock, Materials sent by customers for repair or processing. The company tracks them but doesn‚Äôt own them financially.
Free‚Äëof‚Äëcharge samples or promotional items stock is managed for logistics but not valued in accounting. Consignment or project stock sometimes tracked non‚Äëvaluated to simplify accounting integration with external parties. Packaging materials not always non‚Äëvaluated. If packaging is a cost element (e.g., branded boxes), it can be valuated. If packaging is reusable or customer‚Äëprovided, it‚Äôs often non‚Äëvaluated. Decision depends on whether the company wants packaging costs reflected in financial statements.

Now the question is who pays and how consumption Is Handled. So the thing is customer‚Äëowned stock will be bear by customer the cost, company only provides service. I its a free samples, cost absorbed by the company at procurement stage itself. Consumption doesn‚Äôt trigger valuation postings.
In case of packaging is valuated, consumption posts to expense accounts; if non‚Äëvaluated, only quantity updates occur.

SAP MM vs. EWM Handling

SAP MM: Material types like UNBW (non‚Äëvaluated) or NLAG (non‚Äëstock) define valuation behavior. No FI postings for goods movements of UNBW materials.

SAP EWM: Still requires a product master and stock representation. Non‚Äëvaluated products behave like normal stock logistically (putaway, picking, bin management). Difference: No valuation integration with MM/FI. EWM tracks quantities for warehouse operations but doesn‚Äôt push value postings to MM.

Text Items in SAP EWM
Definition: Items in a delivery or warehouse request that are purely descriptive.
System behavior: No product master required.
Do not create deliveries, warehouse tasks, or stock movements.
Used for notes, instructions, or references (e.g., ‚ÄúHandle with care‚Äù or ‚ÄúCustomer request‚Äù).

They can appear in delivery documents but remain informational. No exceptions‚Äîtext items never trigger logistics execution.

Hope my explanation is fine for your understanding. if you have any more question, feel free to ask. if satisfied then confirm.

entry.title: Re: Long text formatting options - editor
entry.content:
Hi @isabelle1993 ,

That's true, SAP allows some flexibility in replacing or improving the long text editor. You can configure whether the editor uses the standard SAP GUI editor, the MS Word-based editor, or other text-based options. However, replacing the editor entirely is limited to what SAP provides‚Äîcustomization usually involves adjusting system settings, user parameters, or using Business Client integration rather than installing a completely new editor
To solve your issue, I suggest standardizing on one editor (preferably the line editor for consistency) and using ABAP enhancements to normalize line breaks before texts are passed to subsequent systems. If you want to explore editor settings, check SAP GUI options under Utilities ‚Üí Settings ‚Üí Word Processing or consult your Basis team to enforce editor consistency.

entry.title: Re: purchase order text not updating in BAPI_material_Sav...
entry.content:
Hi @tadao_ando ,

I understand your issue as its one of the limitation of BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA and BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEREPLICA when trying to update PO text (Purchasing text). The error message MG 157 ‚ÄúPO text cannot be edited‚Äù usually means the BAPI is not the right interface for that field, because PO texts are technically handled as long texts in SAP, not as part of the material master core segments.

This if happening because BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA only updates material master data (basic data, purchasing views, sales views, etc.), but long texts like PO text are stored separately in STXH/STXL tables and managed via SAPscript / Smartform text objects. The PO text is linked to material master but technically maintained via text object MATERIAL and text ID BEST (Purchasing). That‚Äôs why you see intermittent success ‚Äî sometimes the proxy passes the text correctly, but often the BAPI ignores or rejects it.

Use SAVE_TEXT / CREATE_TEXT function modules, These are designed to update long texts. You can call SAVE_TEXT after your BAPI call to ensure the PO text is written. Text object: MATERIAL, Text ID: BEST, Language: EN (or relevant). Then commit with COMMIT WORK.

Use BAPI_SERVICE_TEXTS or BAPI_MATERIAL_GETTEXTS / BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVE_TEXTS. SAP provides text-specific BAPIs for material texts. BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVE_TEXTS is the clean alternative to update PO texts without hitting the MG 157 error.

Batch Input / LSMW (fallback) If you need mass updates and BAPI doesn‚Äôt cover your scenario, a batch input recording (transaction MM02 ‚Üí Purchasing view ‚Üí PO text) can be used.

You can also use Enhancement / BAdI
If you must stick with BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA, you can enhance it via BAdI BADI_MATERIAL_REF or BADI_MATERIAL_MASTER to hook in text updates.
This way, the BAPI call triggers your custom logic to update PO texts via SAVE_TEXT.

Hope your issue has been resolve, if yes confirm or let me know if you get any other error

entry.title: Securing Enterprise AI on SAP BTP: Zero Trust Authentication with SAP AI Core
entry.content:
(Jana Subramanian serves as Head of Cybersecurity and Compliance for SEA and is a Fellow of Information Privacy (FIP), awarded by the International Association of Privacy Professionals (IAPP). In this role, Jana supports strategic customer engagements on cybersecurity, data privacy, multi-cloud security integration architecture, contractual assurance, audit, and compliance.)

Introduction:

If you are building AI-powered applications on SAP BTP with SAP AI Core, understanding how authentication works is essential. This blog walks through the complete SAML-to-OAuth flow from corporate SSO to securely calling AI services, using simple diagrams and clear explanations. Along the way, we also clarify common misconceptions about SAML assertions, token handling, and why your application never deals with SAML directly.

This post does not cover detailed configuration steps. Instead, it focuses on the high-level concepts and end-to-end flow to help you build a clear mental model of how authentication works in SAP BTP.  By the end, you will understand the overall process from user login to AI inference, illustrated step-by-step for easier comprehension.

Step: 1

User Enters Application URL The authentication journey begins when a user opens their web browser and enters the URL for the SAP BTP application. At this initial stage, the user is unauthenticated, and the browser sends an HTTP GET request (unauthenticated at this stage). This step represents the standard entry point where the user knocks on the door of the application before any security checks are applied.

Step 2:

Traffic Reaches App Router / Application Once the traffic reaches the SAP BTP Application (or App Router), the component acts as a security gatekeeper. It immediately inspects the request to see if a valid session or OAuth 2.0 JWT token already exists. In this scenario, because it is a new login attempt, no valid token is found, and the application recognizes that it must initiate the authentication process to protect its resources .

Step 3:

Application Redirects to XSUAA Instead of handling authentication itself or sending the user directly to the corporate Identity Provider, the application redirects the user's browser to XSUAA, the platform's OAuth 2.0 Authorization Server. This is a critical architectural design: the application initiates a standard OAuth Authorization Code Flow, effectively delegating all complexity regarding SAML and corporate identity to XSUAA.

Step 4:

XSUAA Generates SAML AuthnRequest & Redirects to IdP XSUAA now takes over the orchestration by generating a SAML Authentication Request (AuthnRequest) and redirecting the user's browser to the corporate Identity Provider (IdP), such as Azure AD or Okta . By handling this step, XSUAA acts as the Service Provider on behalf of the application, managing the trust configuration and specific SAML protocol requirements so the application doesn't have to.

Step 5:

Authenticates User and Issues SAML Assertion The user completes their login at the corporate IdP (using passwords or MFA), and upon success, the IdP generates a cryptographically signed SAML assertion . Crucially, the browser POSTs this assertion directly to XSUAA's Assertion Consumer Service (ACS) endpoint‚Äînot to the application. This ensures the application never touches the XML or handles the certificate validation, keeping the application logic clean and secure.

Step 6:

XSUAA Performs SAML to OAuth Token Exchange Upon receiving the SAML assertion, XSUAA validates the digital signature and timestamps, and automatically maps the SAML attributes to OAuth scopes . Once validation passes, XSUAA generates an OAuth 2.0 authorization code and redirects the browser back to the application's callback URL with this code in the query string . This step effectively translates the enterprise SAML identity into a modern OAuth artifact transparently.

Step 7:

Application Exchanges Authorization Code for OAuth Tokens The application receives the authorization code and immediately performs a secure, server-to-server POST request to XSUAA to exchange it for an access token and a refresh token . Because this request includes the application's Client ID and Client Secret, XSUAA verifies the application's identity before issuing the tokens, which are then stored securely in the server-side session .

Step 8:

Application Calls GenAI Hub API Using Access Token With a valid OAuth access token securely stored, the SAP BTP application can now invoke the Generative AI Hub. To do this, the application sends an HTTP request‚Äîtypically a POST‚Äîto the GenAI Hub API endpoint containing the user‚Äôs input or inference prompt. The most important part of this request is the Authorization header, where the application includes the JWT access token using the standard OAuth bearer format (Authorization: Bearer <JWT>) . This step represents the handoff from authentication to operation: the application is no longer proving identity but instead using the validated token to access protected AI services. The GenAI Hub will then independently validate the JWT before forwarding the request to SAP AI Core for model execution.

Step 9:

Gen AI Hub Validates JWT LOCALLY When the application makes an API call to the Gen AI Hub using the access token, the Hub validates the token locally rather than calling back to XSUAA . By using cached public keys (JWKS) from XSUAA, Gen AI Hub can instantly verify the token's signature, expiration, and scopes . This local validation approach significantly reduces latency (from ~100ms to ~10ms) while maintaining cryptographic security.

Step 10

AI Core Independently Validates JWT (Zero Trust) Adhering to Zero Trust principles, when Gen AI Hub forwards the request to SAP AI Core, AI Core does not blindly trust the previous validation . Instead, it independently validates the token again using the same local JWKS method to verify the signature and ensure the user has the specific permissions required for the target resource group . This defense-in-depth strategy ensures that even if an upstream service were compromised, unauthorized access is prevented.

Step 11:

Response Returns to User After the AI Core executes the inference on the model, the results travel back up the chain‚Äîfrom AI Core to Gen AI Hub, and finally to the application . The application receives the AI-generated response and renders it to the user interface. The user sees the result immediately, completely unaware of the sophisticated "authentication dance" and multi-layered security checks that occurred in the background.

Complete Authentication and Authorization Flow:

The complete architecture brings all these components together, visualizing the robust interplay between the User, App Router, XSUAA, Identity Provider, and AI services. It highlights the separation of concerns where XSUAA manages identity federation, the application handles business logic via OAuth, and the backend AI services enforce security through independent, local Zero Trust validation.

If you still have a challenge in understanding technicalities, here is a layman point of view for better comprehension:

  1. You want to enter the building (BTP App)
  2. Security guard (App Router) says "Show me your badge"
  3. You don't have one, so guard sends you to Badge Office (XSUAA)
  4. Badge Office says "Prove you work here - go to HR (IdP)"
  5. HR checks your ID (username/password + MFA)
  6. HR gives you a signed letter (SAML) for Badge Office
  7. Badge Office checks HR's signature ‚úì
  8. Badge Office gives you a CLAIM TICKET (authorization code) - NOT the badge yet!
  9. You give the claim ticket to the guard (App Router)
  10. Guard takes your claim ticket + their secret password to Badge Office
  11. Badge Office verifies claim ticket + guard's credentials
  12. Badge Office NOW gives the guard your access badge (OAuth token)
  13. Guard stores your badge securely and lets you in
  14. Inside building, each room (Gen AI Hub, AI Core) scans your badge
  15. Each room verifies badge locally using master key
  16. You get access

Common Misconception

 

#

Misconception

Reality (Correct Explanation)

1

The application receives or processes the SAMLResponse.

The SAMLResponse is posted only to XSUAA (ACS endpoint). The application never interacts with SAML.

2

XSUAA forwards the SAML assertion to the application.

XSUAA converts the SAML assertion into an OAuth Authorization Code, then into JWT tokens. No SAML leaves XSUAA.

3

SAP BTP applications authenticate directly with the IdP.

Apps authenticate only with XSUAA, not the IdP. The IdP authenticates users, not applications.

4

GenAI Hub or AI Core call XSUAA to validate JWTs.

Both services validate tokens locally using JWKS. No introspection call is made to XSUAA.

5

AI Core does not need to revalidate the JWT if GenAI Hub validated it already.

AI Core enforces Zero Trust and performs its own independent JWT validation.

6

OAuth Authorization Codes are long-lived.

Authorization Codes are short-lived (seconds) and single-use only.

7

Token lifetimes are fixed and universal.

Token lifetimes (access/refresh/session) are configurable per subaccount or client.

8

JWTs contain passwords or sensitive authentication data.

JWTs include claims only (audience, scopes, expiry, user ID). Credentials and MFA data never appear inside a token.

9

OAuth tokens are returned through browser redirects.

Token exchange happens only server-side between the app backend and XSUAA. Tokens never travel in URLs.

10

GenAI Hub or AI Core receive SAML attributes.

Downstream services receive JWT scopes, not SAML attributes. SAML-to-scope mapping happens in XSUAA.

11

The application should call AI Core directly.

Best practice: App ‚Üí GenAI Hub ‚Üí AI Core. GenAI Hub manages token validation, routing, and observability.

12

Refresh tokens are always issued.

Refresh tokens are issued only if allowed by the OAuth client configuration.

13

The IdP decides which OAuth scopes the app gets.

IdP only provides identity attributes. XSUAA assigns scopes based on role collections and SAML group mappings.

14

SAML and OAuth are separate flows.

They form a single chained flow: SAML user authentication ‚Üí XSUAA ‚Üí OAuth token issuance ‚Üí JWT for APIs.

Key Benefits

 

Benefit

Why It Matters

How the Architecture Enables It

1. Clear Separation of Concerns

Reduces application complexity and security risk.

XSUAA absorbs all SAML, federation, and identity-provider logic; applications speak only OAuth.

2. Seamless Single Sign-On (SSO)

Smooth user experience with no repeated logins.

SAML authentication happens once via the corporate IdP; OAuth tokens propagate downstream automatically.

3. Zero Trust Validation

Ensures no service blindly trusts another‚Äîimproves overall security posture.

GenAI Hub and AI Core independently validate JWTs locally using JWKS.

4. Defense-in-Depth Security

Multiple layers of verification block misuse even if one component is compromised.

SAML assertions validated at XSUAA ‚Üí JWT validated at GenAI Hub ‚Üí validated again at AI Core.

5. No Exposure of SAML to Applications

Prevents incorrect handling of complex SAML logic by developers.

All SAML exchanges occur strictly between IdP and XSUAA (ACS endpoint).

6. Standards-Based Interoperability

Easier integration, maintainability, and compatibility with enterprise systems.

Uses industry standards (SAML 2.0, OAuth 2.0, JWT, JWKS).

7. High Performance Token Validation

Reduces network latency and improves inference speed.

Local JWT validation avoids calls back to XSUAA for each request.

8. Scalability Across Services

Allows multiple SAP services to trust the same identity securely.

A single JWT can be validated independently by GenAI Hub and AI Core.

9. Strong Cryptographic Guarantees

Protects against tampering, interception, and replay attacks.

Signed SAMLResponse + signed JWT + short-lived authorization codes.

10. Invisible Complexity for End Users

Users face no friction, even though the architecture is advanced.

Redirects, token exchanges, and validations happen fully behind the scenes.

11. Centralized Identity Governance

Simplifies role management and compliance.

XSUAA handles role collections, scope assignment, and mapping from IdP attributes.

12. Clean Application Code

Faster development, fewer bugs, and clearer security boundaries.

Application deals only with Bearer tokens‚Äînever SAML assertions or IdP protocols.

 

Conclusion

We have now traced the complete lifecycle of a request starting from a simple browser click and ending with a sophisticated AI inference. The elegance of this architecture lies in its separation of concerns. XSUAA handles the heavy lifting by absorbing all the complexity of SAML and corporate identity federation, allowing your application to stay clean and focused, speaking only standard OAuth. Just as important, security on SAP BTP is not a single gate check. Through local JWT validation and Zero Trust principles, services such as the Generative AI Hub and SAP AI Core independently verify every incoming request using cached public signing keys. This provides true defense in depth without compromising performance.

For the end user, all of this, redirects, token exchanges, validations, and cryptographic guarantees, remains completely transparent. They log in once and simply get to work. By understanding the rationale behind these architectural diagrams, it is easier to design SAP Business AI driven applications that are operationally robust and secure by design.

entry.title: My Experience with the New SAP Exam Format¬†(2026)
entry.content:
Starting from November 2025, SAP officially introduced a significant change to its certification journey: an open-book, scenario-based exam format. This new approach is currently in pilot for selected certifications, including the SAP BTP Solution Architect exam.

Details about format here: Reimagining certification in the age of AI

Last week, I had the chance to take this new exam for the certificate ‚ÄúSAP BTP Solution Architect‚Äù and I want to share my honest experience, especially for those preparing for it soon.

After reading the new update from SAP (above link), I learn some more details in a blog in SAP community:

How to Prepare for SAP‚Äôs New Certification‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäSAP Community

However, it‚Äôs still not very clear for me how it looks like in the actual exam. So I gave it a try. For the ‚ÄúSAP BTP Solution Architect‚Äù, it‚Äôs a ‚Äúscenario-based‚Äù exam format, where you need to play the role of a solution architect, designing the solution for a use case, then pitch the solution to AI avatar, or record a video and upload for expert review.

Unlike the previous exam format, where you need to setup some software (private browser) to take a prottor-monitored multiple-choice exam, in this new format, you will start directly from SAP learning website. This is the first look at the new exam format.

(To have this view, you must have purchased the SAP Certification Subcription; I will share in another post)

SAP Certificate landing page, where you can start the exam

After pressing on the ‚ÄúGo to Certification Exam‚Äù, the website will open a wizard like dialog to guide you through the process, which is quite user friendly:

SAP Certification Exam‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäScenario Based Assessment‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäAI Roleplay

For the exam of ‚ÄúSolution Architect‚Äù, you will be assigned to a use case, where you play the architect role to propose a solution to project stakeholders. The use case resembles the actual use case in one project.

For example, in my exam, I need to design a soluton for Field Service Maintainance Engineer to efficiently get and update data with S/4 systems, while they‚Äôre working at customer site.

After reading the use case, once you‚Äôre ready, you can choose 1 out of 2 options to proceed with the pitching part.

For the next step, you will have 2 options to join the xam:

  • AI Roleplay with AI Guidance.
  • Record Video with Human Review.

I tried both, and share my experience as below:

1. A Fresh Concept: Scenario-Based + AI Roleplay

The most exciting part of the new format is the ‚ÄúRoleplay with AI‚Äù feature. Instead of answering static questions, you interact with an AI avatar acting as your stakeholder, and you must propose and justify your architecture on SAP BTP.

This idea is brilliant‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit mimics real project work and tests your ability to think, design, and explain like a true architect.

However‚Ä¶ the reality wasn‚Äôt as smooth as expected.

2. Technical Issues: The AI Mode Was Not Stable

Despite an impressive concept, the AI roleplay mode repeatedly failed during my attempts. I tried everything:

  • Company laptop and personal MacBook
  • Corporate network, home Wi-Fi, mobile hotspot
  • Multiple browsers and system setups

Yet the final step always returned the same message:

‚ÄúAn error occurred. Please refresh the page and try again. If the issue persists, contact the support team for assistance.‚Äù

AI Roleplay option‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääerror

The other option with Human review also didn‚Äôt work:

Human review option‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääerror

Since SAP requires exam submission within 24 hours, the pressure was real. I opened a support ticket, but even after a full working day, there was no response.

3. The Backup Plan: Human Review

Fortunately, late in the day, one of my setups finally allowed me to switch to the ‚ÄúTraditional Assessment‚Äù option, with human review my recording. This required me to:

  • Record and upload a video explaining my architecture
  • Wait for a manual evaluation by an SAP expert

For this option, things are very ‚Äúgeneric‚Äù. SAP does not provides any details on the expectation of the video. All you can do is to prepare the best solution, and present it, during the 2 hours period.

After submitting your video, you will get the result immediately with the AI Roleplace approach. But with the human review approach, you will need to wait for a long time to get the result. During this period, if you enter the certification page again, you will get the ‚ÄúIn Review‚Äù status:

 

The downside?
 The waiting time for results is now 20 days.
 This delay is a huge gap in the expectation of exam taker in this fast-paced world.

4. Final Thoughts: Great Idea, but Needs Stability

I truly appreciate SAP‚Äôs direction. A scenario-based, open-book exam that simulates real project challenges is the right way forward. It evaluates real skills‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänot memorization.

But the instability of the AI mode currently holds back the full potential of this format. When candidates must fall back to manual review, the process becomes:

  • Slow
  • Costly
  • Frustrating
  • Uncertain

For exam takers, waiting nearly a month for results is a painful experience.

5. Looking Ahead

I hope SAP can quickly stabilize the AI roleplay feature. When it works, it will elevate the certification experience and set a new benchmark for professional exams.

The concept is powerful.
 The execution just needs more refinement.

And once it‚Äôs stable, I believe this format will truly redefine how SAP professionals prove their expertise in the future.
